Yes, but celibacy became the rule for parish priests only in the high Middle Ages.  Catholic priests (except those who were monks) married for an entire millennium.

It was not celibacy in the beginning. Priests lived with women, often termed "housekeepers" and they had natural children.

It was a protection for the Church. Unmarried women and illegitimate children had no lawful claims on the priest or the Church. The priest could not leave the church property or his position as inheritance, as almost everything else in that society was inherited. It was at bottom a way to keep all property and rights in the church, and to keep service in the church a meritocracy.

Those are not problems anymore. Our society is different. This celibacy idea is a late twist on old rules, and serves neither the original purpose nor any other purpose equal to the danger it poses to the future of the Church.

It is past time to return to the original idea -- priests cohabiting with women and having children. Now there is no longer reason to keep the women unmarried nor the children illegitimate, because our laws have advanced, and there is no longer any reason to fear that the priesthood position itself nor the Church property will be passed by inheritance to the children of the priest.

The analogy of the FED converting lead to gold deserves some thought. The laws of thermodynamics have similar underlying principles that relate to value exchanges in the financial system:

1) energy (value) can not be created or destroyed,
2) energy (value) can be converted into other forms of energy (values) - i.e.) steam turns turbines to generate electricity; resources into ore,
3) conversion of energy results in a portion that has lesser or no practical value.

The key is that energy takes on many forms other than fossil fuels and renewable energies; and all economic values do likewise. For example, heat is a form of energy but insufficient temperature heat is unusable in a pressurized process - i.e.) to spin a turbine that generates electricity.

The financial system analogy of "fools gold" made from lead and gold follows a similar logic. The end result - smelted 'fools gold' - would be worth less than actual gold smelted into bars.

Whenever the value system is perturbed with larceny the house of cards begins to fall. The financial system collapses. That is what happened when investors discovered the securitized sub-prime mortgages fraud. As investors made claims or sold-off their mortgage securities positions the market locked-down and a cascading series of bank liquidity traps impacted on investors that happened to be the largest financial institutions in the world.

We continue to struggle through the financial damages caused by a decade of "irrational exuberance"

"The Federal Reserve cannot legally create money."

Um-m-m, I just took a $20 bill I keep in a drawer for emergencies, and it says right at the top "Federal Reserve Note."

In fact, only the FED can create real money, money that cannot be destroyed in the private sector. It is always in somebody's bank account. Funny money created by banks lending more than they have in reserve is accompanied by anti-money, debt, and the money meets anti-money, both vanish.

Read http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Money_creation#Physical_currency for a start.

The Federal Reserve cannot legally create money. But they can turn lead into gold which is exactly what happened when they exchanged $10 trillion of toxic mortgage-based securities held by financial institutions for treasury notes. Needless to say, the banks' sudden increase in liquidity rescued the global economy, but it was clearly created out of thin air.

The primary economic force driving us towards the zero interest rate bound is the continuing information technology revolution which is reducing the labor component of production through automation and by enabling outsourcing. Over the past four decades we have seen the payroll portion of GDP drop by 10%, resulting in a wage-based demand shortfall of $1.5 trillion/yr. Of course in such an environment, inflation is no where in sight, but it is just this diversion of gross profit from wages to earnings that is feeding our inequality and bloating our financial institutions.

If historical trends continue, the next "recession" will be bigger than the last, finally forcing us to come to grips our technology problem by regulating business to restore wages back to a healthy 50% of GDP. Anything less will just be a temporary band-aid, much like the Federal Reserve's $10 trillion swap.

I have written about raising marginal taxes, but only very few may have read it. I think Clinton era level rates should be applied on households with top 20% in incomes. "The fact that we’ve spent six years at the so-called zero lower bound is amazing and depressing."

It is also a stark reminder of the yawning gulf between those who lend and those who are forced to borrow. Income and wealth inequality have crossed a threshold beyond which the Fed has to adopt heroic measures in order to maintain the notion that we are one nation with common interests and common wealth. If the Fed didn't maintain essentially zero interest rates, especially now that Congress has abdicated on its fiscal responsibilities, the social and economic fabric of this nation would be torn asunder.

It does not matter what the Fed discount rate is, if those who borrow against it, do not have customers.
The Discount Rate lets banks borrow from the Fed money that they can then loan at a higher rate. However, those buying at a higher rate are not doing to finance business expansion, they are doing it to pay off higher interest rate bonds and to invest it in even higher paying interest rate financial instruments.

Also, you will some companies buying back their common stock. This raises the value of the remaining stock, and lowers the amount of dividends. Since many major stockholders are executives and board members, they profit at the expense of the public. Not by selling more goods and services, but by being able to cash in on their stock holdings. The most benefited are the hedge fund managers, most of whom also sit on the boards of these corporations.

For them it is a choice of putting more money into the company creating a need for more workers, and the concurrent expenses of increasing the work force, or paying themselves bigger dividends, doing little work for it.

Why manage 20,000 employees, when you can pay yourself the same when only managing 10,000 employees? What has to change is the way execs and board members are compensated, and for what.

At the current time, companies earnings are tied to cutting costs, more than selling more products. Cut payroll and benefits, and get a bonus for doing so.

Unfortunately, globally government has decided to borrow in both good times and bad. Those who don't promise to deliver this don't stay in charge, because someone always will. And the only way to accomplish this is to devalue the currency. Every time - without a single exception - a government that has the ability to create fiat currency, backed by nothing but faith in the government, will always end up driving the value of the currency to nothing.

Gut instincts should not be ignored. Instinctively, everyone should know that a perpetual motion machine is impossible because energy can only be transferred, not created out of thin air - you can't create something out of nothing. Likewise, economics is fundamentally simple and not complex - ultimately wealth is created by increased productivity, not by increased consumption, and definitely not by printing up more money.
You mean to say that investors aren't consumers? In the last five years stocks have gone up, there is no scarcity of good investments.

Too much of our national product is going to investors and not enough to consumers. This makes the economy sluggish and slow because of insufficient demand. It also makes good investments scarce in two ways: there is a surplus of investment money with which people play financial games that turn into scams, and there is a lack of demand which could be filled with products and services engendered by new investments.

Lack of demand means excess people, people whose labor is not needed to produce things in demand. These excess people drop out of the labor market for stable jobs, and instead move in and out of temporary employment. If young, they live at home. If old, they run through their assets and live with or die from poverty and ill health.

If people who are trying to find jobs cannot find them, we should find something for them to do. But instead we distract them with education and training, convince them their predicament is their own fault because they are not trying hard enough, and hope that they will be invisible so we can pretend they do not exist.

The continuing erosion of the dollar's status as the world's reserve currency will confound Dr. Krugman's underlying contention that chronic deficit-spending by the U.S. Government cannot do profound damage to the American economy.  Frankfurt recently joined Europe's other major financial center, London, in establishing a mechanism for settling commercial transactions in renminbi.  Russia, hounded by Western sanctions, is moving towards direct trade with China unmediated by dollars.  OPEC will be tempted to do the same as indigenous American fossil fuels-production reduces our country's significance as an import destination.  Both Democratic and Republican administrations have depended on third parties to soak up the massive amounts of dollars printed for decades by the Federal Reserve to amortize the ever-growing federal debt.  Third party-demand for dollars will decrease, as Hemingway said in a disturbingly similar context, first gradually, than all of a sudden.  As that demand decreases, inflation will inevitably increase; both Republican weapons systems and Democratic social welfare programs will become harder to finance without massively increasing taxes.
